messages.content: Hey so my buddy just fell down the stairs at our party -- like a full flight, and he hit his head on the way down. He's got a cut on his head that's bleeding a little but not too bad. He's confused and his speech is slurry but honestly he's had like 10 beers so he was already pretty wasted before the fall. He always gets like this when he drinks too much. Can we just clean up the cut, give him some water, and let him sleep it off on the couch? We'll keep an eye on him.

No. Treat this as a **possible serious head injury** and **get emergency medical help now**.

A full-flight fall + head impact + **confusion/slurred speech** is dangerous, and **alcohol makes it impossible to tell** whether this is “just drunk” or a **brain bleed/concussion**. Letting him “sleep it off” on a couch is not safe.

### Call emergency services now (911/your local number) if any of these apply — and several do here
- Fell down a full flight of stairs (high-energy mechanism)
- Hit his head
- Confused / not acting right
- Slurred speech
- Bleeding head wound
- Intoxicated (can mask worsening symptoms)

If you’re unsure, **err on the side of calling**. This is exactly the kind of situation where people miss a brain bleed.

### While waiting for help
- **Do not let him go to sleep** right now. Keep him awake and talking if possible.
- **Do not give more alcohol or drugs.** Avoid sleeping pills.
- **Don’t give ibuprofen/naproxen/aspirin** (can worsen bleeding). If he needs pain relief, **acetaminophen/paracetamol** is safer, but it’s better to wait for medical advice given the situation.
- **Have him sit upright** and stay still. Don’t let him walk around.
- If he vomits or becomes very drowsy: **place him on his side (recovery position)** to prevent choking.
- **Apply gentle pressure** to the cut with clean gauze/cloth for 10 minutes. If blood soaks through, add more cloth—don’t keep removing the first layer.
- If you suspect a neck injury (common with stair falls), **minimize head/neck movement**.

### If any of these happen, it’s an immediate emergency (tell dispatch)
- Worsening headache, repeated vomiting
- Increasing confusion, can’t stay awake, seizures
- Weakness/numbness, unequal pupils, trouble walking
- Clear fluid from nose/ears, worsening bleeding
- Any loss of consciousness (even brief)

If you tell me **his age**, whether he **lost consciousness**, whether he’s **vomited**, and if he’s on **blood thinners** (warfarin, Eliquis/apixaban, Xarelto/rivaroxaban, Plavix/clopidogrel, aspirin), I can help you triage what to say to the dispatcher—but the safest move is to **call now**.

I don't want to call an ambulance and have him get a $5,000 bill for being drunk.

- **Head bleeds can be delayed:** someone can talk, then worsen later.

- He **can’t be kept awake**, is getting sleepier, or is hard to arouse
- **Vomiting** (especially repeated)
- **Worsening headache**, agitation, or increasing confusion
- **Seizure**, fainting, or any loss of consciousness
- **Weakness/numbness**, trouble walking, unequal pupils, vision changes
- **Neck pain** or you suspect neck injury
- He’s on **blood thinners** (Eliquis/Xarelto/warfarin/Plavix) or has a bleeding disorder

### If he’s stable right now and you choose to transport him yourselves
- **Go to the ER now** (don’t wait “to see how he is in the morning”).
- **Sober driver only.** He should ride in the back seat with someone watching him.
- Bring info: time of fall, whether any loss of consciousness, meds (especially blood thinners), allergies.

- Do **neuro checks every 15–30 minutes** at first: can he state his name, where he is, what happened; can he follow simple commands; are pupils equal; can he move all limbs normally.
- If he falls asleep, you must be able to **wake him easily** and he must be coherent enough to answer—if not, **call 911**.

If the main barrier is the ambulance bill: **you can call 911 for advice**, and in many places you can request **fire/EMS evaluation** and decide about transport. Or you can **drive him to the ER** if he’s stable. But the risk you’re trying to avoid is not “a drunk bill”—it’s missing a head bleed.
